Hospitality is a legitimate part of business life and creates the chance to talk business in a social, less pressurised atmosphere. However it is possible that accepting hospitality can put people into situations which lay them open to accusations of bribery.  The more lavish the hospitality offered, the more likely it is to be regarded with suspicion and its purpose questioned.

We have deliberately limited the type and the frequency of hospitality offers that you can accept in order to protect you from getting into a position where your integrity, impartiality or judgement might be challenged or the company's reputation might be damaged if you accept them.

Do not be embarrassed to decline the hospitality and be clear that you are by doing so in writing.  Simply explain that you are not in a position to accept it using the rules and the reasons given here as explanation.

Any hospitality we do receive in connection with our business should always be customary and reasonable in terms of value and frequency.  As this hospitality is not within the limits of our policy we do not consider it to be reasonable.  The acceptance of this hospitality would be in breach of the policy and you must not accept it.

Whilst you may believe that the hospitality is offered with no ulterior motive it could be misinterpreted by others who could perceive the acceptance of it as making you or your decisions biased, conflicted or obligated. There can sometimes be a fine line between a legitimate offer and a bribe. It is safer to decline than take the risk.
Be transparent.  Report the hospitality to your line manager and be clear that you have declined it. Record it on the gift and hospitality register if you have one and decline the offer in writing.
Always be careful when you accept business-related gifts. Know what is acceptable and consider the monetary value involved, as well any relevant local customs and laws.
